values:
I'm done.
as far as I want to be.

In its entirety, you could say that this project shifts mediums, though they haven't all been done at one time.
Comic
to
Essay
to
something yet to come

I'm excited; I've been thinking up my themed meal idea for Thursday night.

Everything will be red or heart-shaped!!!

Roasted heart-shaped red sweet potatoes
Tomato soup
Heart-shaped grilled tempeh and vegetable sandwiches (with red onions and red pepper)
Red grape, red pluot, pomegranate fruit salad
and heart carved radishes as place settings.


eeep!

I walked to work, went into the office and told the manager that I didn't want to be there all day. so I'm home.

Yesterday I finished my 6-essays and application for a scholarship.
Cooked my parents lunch.
Went to work.
Did some shopping.
Made bread.
Cleaned up some things around the house.
Edited the animation from the workshop I taught.
Helped take care of my mother.

and today I woke up early to finish the bread, mail the application, help my mom, and walk to work before deciding not to be busy all day again.


I'm excited to go home on Sunday.

I've got a ticket.

I'll be spending new year's eve with Micky and Diana again, but this time we'll be in London.

Things are working out, and I am thankful.

My novel is coming along well. Classes are flowing swimmingly. My mother seems to be doing well emotionally. Friends are experiencing many different good things: finished thesis, possible love, good work, et cetera.

After some issues with signing up, I now have registered for my spring semester classes. I will have to go to school on my birthday this way, and it seems that Bread Wednesday will have to change to Tuesday or Friday, but I'm fairly excited for some of these classes.

Monday
12:30-3:20 Philosophical Issues in Film
3:30-4:50 New Millenium Studies
5:00-6:20 Writing & Rhetoric II

Wednesday
12:30-3:20 Public History: Presenting & Interpreting the Past
3:30-4:50 New Millenium Studies
5:00-6:20 Writing & Rhetoric II

Thursday
10:30-12:20 Grammar for Journalists (If I don't pass out of it)
12:30-3:20 Reporting & Writing I

I decided to do NaNoWriMo (National Novel Writing Month) this year. It's my first time trying it and I don't typically write fiction, but it's a lot of fun so far. I'm almost at my goal for the day of 5000 words; ten percent of the way to being complete. It's surprising that I still like the story as much as when I started it, but I'm going to treat it like my animation pieces so only tiny tidbits will be seen before it's finished.

<lj-cut text="a few selected words mixed together">playing all afternoon in her blanket fort... kicked her gently... and neighed raucously in her ear... the table and tea... commanded... the motionless girl... to flow out of a cut in... a fallen saucer beneath her... lemon tea... pond.</lj-cut>

My mother's surgery was today. I called this morning saying that they would be in my thoughts and that I wished everything go smoothly. Apparently, the surgery was early this morning (I had assumed it was later) and they did not receive my message until they got home. I feel bad for not being there with her, and bad for not thinking of her at the time it happened either. Not being there in reality or spirit is incredibly taxing at times. So for feeling down on myself all day, I felt highly productive. Last night I finished making most of my D&D set-up for Friday Today I dressed up, did my hair Made a new note for the bathroom Baked a Sicilian Twist for Bread Day (which I dubbed last week as every Wednesday) Helped cook dinner with giant leaves that, when raw, made my entire mouth burn Made a box fort Aquired an amp to use and practiced my guitar and played computer games, watched Arthur and Spongebob, and did laundry. Now I am hiding from everyone in my room instead of going to dinner downstairs. because I feel like I've abandoned my family. no matter what I accomplished today, I still feel upset.

I can never seem to manage falling asleep before 2am. And then in class tomorrow I tend to reach a half-awake state during my first class because the seats are like that of a movie theater... I just slouch down to rest my head after the first hour has passed and I realize that there's still two hours left in the room. It's not as if I really fall asleep, but it probably looks like I'm totally out of it, and I feel bad for the teacher because it's a good class.

If I could force myself to sleep earlier, I would. Though it seems that watching movies, playing games, and creating D&D figures and grids for the game I'm DMing are all more worthwhile than sleeping at this time of night.

This weekend has felt especially productive and fun-filled. I toiled away making loaves and loaves of bread for the house's Evolution Party. I prepared bags of Friendship Bread dough to give away as party favors and hand decorated little recipe sheets with three different variations. After throwing off my apron and tossing on my futuristic-blending-in-with-aliens outfit, I danced for a while and joined in on a spontaneous can-can. There was homework to do for the next morning, so I retired from the festivities and went to my room to read.
I woke up several hours later, went to class, and then waited to get picked up for a ride from my housemates. We ventured off to the Museum of Holography and became mesmerized by the glorious functions of light imagery. After getting back to the house, I went to the park and visited some cute sheep and goats and the little petting zoo. Finally, the night completed with a geeky game of D&D.
Today, I decided to dress up. Went to the book sale. Worked on a puzzle. Did some homework. Made baklava and told everyone that tonight's dinner is formal. So we will feast on falafel, melons, and a green bean salad looking fancy at the ping pong dinner table.

and missing the free screening of Darjeeling was worth it, because I made my first hologram in class that night and got to keep it.
I hate that I feel obligated to go to my Monday night class instead of a free preview of the Darjeeling Limited. but we'll be making holograms. but I've been waiting for the movie for months.

So, let me just say that Vrendil Sveit is awesome.

Ze is a magnificent dwarf cleric that tonight helped return a magical hammer to it's rightful owners with the chicken viking and his people, bringing the lizard-man thief to justice. And ze sliced a goblin in half with zir waraxe one-handedly as well as extinguished some curtain fires with a water spell and healed a fellow fighter from being burned.

I love being geeky.

No one ever taught me how to breathe.

Today I discovered that I have, in fact, been breathing inefficiently for over eighteen years.

Even through the daily difficulties or dilemmas, I find myself remaining calm and content. I have time and thought to do yoga. Leisure to sink into a couch and crack down on a puzzle, watch a movie, or listen to my housemates play music. There is enough energy and motivation to do art projects and bake. My French bathroom art installation is pleasing and enjoyable. My improvised raw, vegan, mango-coconut torte was delicious.

Moving away has done wonders that I am incredibly pleased with. Though I miss several people dearly, the distance between us seems irrelevant to my love for them.

I have pondered the whole of emptiness.

and it is fulfilling.

Fantastic for its potential possible ponderings to pour minds over our tea We can create images that will devour other art, though it may be in our minds, empty space is the only place to exhibit these creations.
I've spent a lot of time touring libraries, museums, and creating chalk animation. It doesn't feel like I'm in school.

Since moving to my new home in Chicago I have:

visited Millenium and Grant Park
swum in Lake Michigan
toured the loop
attended school functions
paid my tuition
viewed and created artwork in the Art Institute
gotten a public library card
finished a difficult puzzle
mailed a letter
and bonded with my housemates through baking cookies, playing ping pong, and just hanging out.


I feel accomplished. Tomorrow I'm going to play with my chalkboard wall and camera.

I'm home, and should probably sleep, but my vacation was fantastic. Ask me in person about it because there is too much to write about. Some photos are on my flickr, but not all of them due to storage capacity and the fact that my camera broke.

After the worst time trying to find the co-op that I hoped to live in (this venture involved about 5 hours and several buses, wrong addresses, trains, too-late e-mails, confused civilians, confused travellers, a bad cab ride, and many tears) I found myself a place that I find very comfortable and affordable.

My mother did not feel the same way.

At least the day is over, and I've had a restful few days with hours to just work on puzzles, drink tea, and take naps.

I have escaped. 

to a land where I hide under the blanket typing and playing computer games, at two hours different than you Seattleites.
and I don't miss it. Truthfully, everything was getting to the point where I was always busy and never was really having fun... nomatter what it was that occupied my time. Now, free time is seemingly everywhere to be wasted on streets I don't truly know yet.

ughhh... why is it already Wednesday?
I'm not ready.
There was too much to do, little of it is done.
the two jobs, the party, the trip, the apartments, the school, the video, the animation...    the spare time??

I am tired.

My strange understanding that has developed with the universe is, yet again, apparent in my life's little occurences.

I had made a plan with my regular Sunday night bus driver last week to trade goods. I was going to bring raspberries from my house, and she would bring cherries from her yard. Now, the two of us have become friends through the hours that she has driven me around town. She used to run the 43/44 route on my way home from the NWFF Saturday evenings, and now she drives Sunday nights on my way home from the Metro. We talk about our families and general lives, and I feel as if she is sort of an honorary aunt.
The staff was taking a little too long to clean up at the end of the night, so after my running and jumping around they let me leave a few minutes early to catch my bus. I barely caught it, got on, and was surprised to see a man behind the wheel.
"Are those raspberries?" he asked with a smile.
I said yes, with a slight tone of sadness.
"Taking them home to make jam or something? I love jam." He had a very cheery attitude, and I couldn't help but warm up to him.
"I made jam last week actually. These were going to be for the driver who regulary does this route. We made a deal that I would give her raspberries and she would bring me cherries," I replied.
The driver reached behind his chair, pulled out a plastic bag and handed it to me. It was full of cherries. I couldn't believe that he had the exact thing that I had planned to trade with someone else, and I gave him my berries. He was thrilled to swap goods with me (and didn't seem to expect I was going to trade, but was willing to just give me his fruit) and was incredibly excited about getting some raspberries, and even more happy to learn that they were home-grown.

I don't feel like working.
...stayed up late last night
...couldn't sleep
...semi-creepy "stepford" vibe from the new dentist
...finished typing the interview with Council Member Tom Rasmussen
...writing questions for one Connie Watts, the new Executive Director of Equal Rights Washington.

so I don't want to work.
but I'm smiling about carrying a panoramic x-ray of my teeth with me. because I love that I have three wisdom teeth.

I find our national government strange and not particulary representative of the country's citizens.

FBI statement on what constitutes as a hate crime--
"Congress has defined a hate crime as a 'criminal offense against a person or property motivated in whole or in part by an offender's bias against a race, religion, disability, ethnic origin or sexual orientation.'
There are, of course, many kinds of bias.  Some of the more common kinds are those against race, religion, 
disability, sexual orientation, or ethnicity/national origin.  But, there are also biases against rich 
people, poor people, men who wear long hair and/or beards, people who dress oddly, smokers, 
drinkers, people with diseases such as AIDS, motorcycle gangs, rock musicians, etc."

Graduating Nova doesn't have as great of an impact on me as it does most other students it seems. I don't care that I've accomplished this mark in my life, as recently I have done many other things that I feel were truly difficult or amazing achievements. Tonight was more a look at what my fellow Nova students have done throughout their years and a reminder of the memories we've shared.

And in my yearbook, the last person to sign it was probably the most meaningful to me. I think that I will make her something and try to find out a way to reach her.
I fell asleep more excited than I have been since Christmas Eve of fourth grade. and when morning came, that thrill was greater than I would have ever expected. Lisa Wardle is a (front-page) writer.

This is difficult. My first couple of interviews were with fellow high school kids. Then I had one with a firefighter from Bellevue. Now I'm working on one for Councilman Tom Rasmussen. Politicians are crazy.

Apparently, the MacStore has wifi that carries over to the Metro lobby. Who would have known? 
And who would have guessed that my year to take it easy would become full of millions of projects?
The yearbook cover stencil is made, it features three different designs to make three unique covers.
The yearbook layout is in the works
SIFF is going on
I applied for a promotion at the Metro
Seattle Gay News hired me as a news journalist
Graduation is being planned
School is being finished
Various craft projects for good-byes to teachers are being worked on

Tomorrow is the Seattle Rotary Academic Achievement Luncheon. Friday I'm supposed to go to the GLSEN dinner for the Gay News. Anyone want to tag along to the GLSEN dinner? My publisher said that we have an entire table and was encouraging me to bring people. I think I have to get rid of my ticket to <u>Emma's Bliss</u> at 7pm that night, dinner probably won't be over then. Anyone want that?

I am running around from place to place all the time.
life is tiring
<lj-embed id="1" />

Last night was prom. There were several small problems, involving falling apart corsages and flashless polaroids, but it was enjoyable overall. My date was sweet and adorable. Our picnic in the rose garden was fun. Dancing was various in genres, from Queen to Madonna to 99 Red Balloons to Sir Mix-a-Lot.

Pirates Three was exciting and invigorating during the swashbuckling battle sequences, but the three hour plot was too full of love stories that didn't need to occupy the amount of screen time that they did. The entire backstory of Davy Jones and Callipso could have been edited to about one third of what was shown and still make sense. It continued to tell the same few things repeatedly, making the amount of time that I put into it seem like there should have been a more complicated story to follow. Then there were the two lovebirds who have been chasing eachother all this time, do they finally get together? Is it over-the-top cheesy in one of their final scenes together?
I enjoyed the movie for its humor and stunning visual styles, but would not see it again due to the length and several points of dragging.
I wish that I could sleep.
I walked out of the shower, squeezed some excess water out of my hair, and realized that I hadn't washed out the shampoo.

I hate obligations. I do not want to go to Spirit Fest at school, I have no desire to go. It has been a very stressful week, with schoolwork and working and planning the graduation ceremony and the yearbook and looking for a place to live in Chicago and having my one day off have a plethora of arguments.
I want to rest. but people will expect me to attend Spirit Fest. so I can't.

As the dawn of the SIFF season lies just beyond the horizon, I find myself glad to not be too attached to people. I will not feel bad spending almost every hour of my time at movie theaters by my lovely lonesome. so far, from what I know, these are my plans: edits made. 5/25 Them(midnight) 5/26 Waiter(11am) 5/27 Severance(midnight) 5/28 Paris je t'aime(11am), King of Kong(1:30pm), Team Everest(4pm), Fly Films(7pm), The Aerial(9:30pm) 5/29 Death at a Funeral(7pm) 5/30 Reduce, Reuse, Recycle(7pm), Fido(9:30pm) 6/2 Black Sheep(midnight) 6/4 Dasepo Naughty Girls(9:30pm) 6/5 Cashback(9:30pm) 6/7 Poltergay(7:15pm), American Shopper(9:30pm) 6/11 The Bothersome Man(7pm) 6/15 Trail of the Screaming Forehead(4pm), Confession of Pain(10pm) 6/17 Interview(1:30pm)

I'm unbelievably pleased to find out that one of my favorite bands is from Norway. This will make for a much more fun presentation on the Scandinavian heritage. I would love to talk to someone about the music scene in those countries. Iceland, Norway, Finland... each country's music has a unique sound that I admire. I don't know much about modern Danish and Swedish music, but if you do let me know.

Okay. It's over. 
My interview is done
they'll judge me from that 25 minute run
question and answer from generalized queries
I stuttered through my personal theories
how I'm a leader
who I've encouraged
what's important
how I have flourished
I don't want another disappointment
a "thank you but no" letter sent
Single but gay
I pray to deserve a scholarship from the GSBA

Decisions today,
perhaps already,
I just have to hold my head up steady
wait nervously and try to rest
hope that it was my best.
When they let me know may be soon to you all
but for me it seems already like fall.

It's strange to have this many people to see in such a compacted amount of time. It seems that usually I would get together with a friend maybe once or twice a month. Yesterday Anna and I saw a movie. Today Alison came over to have a cooking party, play croquet, and play Clue. Then I went to have dinner with Hilary, and afterward we swing danced and wandered the UW campus.

Tomorrow is my interview and I'm worried.
What if I don't get any scholarships for college? I want to make it as easy on my parents as possible. I don't want loans. It feels bad to say no to a school that offered me 12,000 a year to go to the one I really want, even though they aren't providing me with any financial aid. I hate money.

If I go to the staff screening, I will probably fall asleep.
If I don't, I will feel as if I have missed out on a good free movie.

Working at a movie theater really dulls the excitement of going out to see one. Or perhaps I'm just too worn out tonight.

Hot Fuzz can wait. I can wait. I already saw about half an hour of it anyway.
If you eat at restaurant next Thursday, make it one that will support a good cause. Dine Out for Life
pogo sticking scooter grocery shopping darts arts and Duct Tape Forever and I took a picture of my roller blading outfit for those who wanted to see it.

oh TMNT, how you bring memories of awesome times.

Raphael, AKA my favorite Turtle, is totally badass.

compday
Originally uploaded by lease a.
Today, pay someone a compliment. It's free, but will give both you and someone else a better feeling about the world that we live in.

I'm organizing a Compliment Day at Nova. I encourage everyone to join in the act of compassion, whether or not you are enrolled at my school.

A coworker told me about this adventure bus company, Green Tortoise, that she went on a few years ago across the country. I think that I will go on one of their trips this summer. I pine to go on the Alaskan trip, but that would require missing graduation...(yes? I don't care as much as others might) or I could travel The Western Front, Death Valley, National Parks, or go Northeast. I want to do something fun this summer. I've been working, it sounds like an exciting thing to spend my money on.

I have everything done. No errands to run, guitar pieces to get replaced, videos to send off, homework to do, colleges to visit, animation classes to TA, essays to submit places...

it feels strange with this freedom.
but people noticed an inner smile.

and I love you.

Today was productive, fun, peculiar, and inspiring.

I worked on getting paid for my animation job.
I sent in my official entry to the Seattle Times.
I decided that I want to enter the  Futurewave Film Contest tomorrow with Gloveless.
I had a City of God hugfest
and tasted cereals (one of which I hated, two which were chai dusted and delicious)
I got my official letter from Columbia, and I'll be leaving in July it seems.
I thought more about this summer, what I want to do. I could go to Croatia with my family, but the idea of a trip by myself or with friends intrigues me. I've got money from savings to spend on a trip, but don't know what to do.

I enter contests because I see no harm in it. If there is a chance of me winning, why not? All of the cruel pranks that Life has thrown at me recently have to equal out with joy. One of the contests might be that needed weight on the balancing scale. How else would I know?
things have not been going well
